citation.article-title: Psychromonas antarcticus gen. nov., sp. nov., A new aerotolerant anaerobic, halophilic psychrophile isolated from pond sediment of the McMurdo ice shelf, antarctica

p.s: Description of Psychromonas antarcticus sp. nov.
Psychromonas antarcticus (ant.arc.ti.cus. L.gen.n., M.L.masc.gen.n., of Antarctica)
Cells 1.3 μm in width and 2.5–6 μm in length.
Growth occurs in the presence of 0–4% NaCl (w/v), optimum at 3%.
Survives freeze-thawing at salt concentrations of 3%, but not in the presence of low salt (< 0.5%).
Does not survive exposure to temperatures of >30°C for more than 20 h or short-term exposure to temperatures of 50°C or greater.
Energy for growth derived by fermenting starch, glycogen, and hexose mono- and disaccharides including N-acetyl glucosamine to acetate, ethanol, formate, lactate and CO2.
Small amounts of butyrate are also produced.

No hydrogen, n-propanol, n-butanol, propionate or succinate are produced as fermentation end products. N-acetyl muramic acid, esculin, lactose, mannose, rhamnose, sorbitol, alaalanine, isoleucine, valine, formate, putrescine, casamino acids, yeast extract, fumarate, lactate, malate, glycerol, xylose and xylan do not support growth.
The organism was isolated from sediment below the cyanobacterial mat of a high-salinity pond on the McMurdo Ice Shelf in Antarctica.
